member.name: T:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.ActiveContext
member.summary:
Contains information about the contexts that a user is using in a session. You can configure Amazon Lex V2 to set a context when an intent is fulfilled, or you can set a context using the , , or operations.
Use a context to indicate to Amazon Lex V2 intents that should be used as follow-up intents. For example, if the active context is order-fulfilled, only intents that have order-fulfilled configured as a trigger are considered for follow up.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.ActiveContext.ContextAttributes
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContextAttributes.
A list of contexts active for the request. A context can be activated when a previous intent is fulfilled, or by including the context in the request.
If you don't specify a list of contexts, Amazon Lex V2 will use the current list of contexts for the session. If you specify an empty list, all contexts for the session are cleared.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.ActiveContext.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The name of the context.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.ActiveContext.TimeToLive
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TimeToLive.
Indicates the number of turns or seconds that the context is active. Once the time to live expires, the context is no longer returned in a response.

member.name: T:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.ActiveContextTimeToLive
member.summary: The time that a context is active. You can specify the time to live in seconds or in conversation turns.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.ActiveContextTimeToLive.TimeToLiveInSeconds
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TimeToLiveInSeconds.
The number of seconds that the context is active. You can specify between 5 and 86400 seconds (24 hours).

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.ActiveContextTimeToLive.TurnsToLive
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TurnsToLive.
The number of turns that the context is active. You can specify up to 20 turns. Each request and response from the bot is a turn.

member.name: T:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.DeleteSessionRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the DeleteSession operation. Removes session information for a specified bot, alias, and user ID.
You can use this operation to restart a conversation with a bot. When you remove a session, the entire history of the session is removed so that you can start again.
You don't need to delete a session. Sessions have a time limit and will expire. Set the session time limit when you create the bot. The default is 5 minutes, but you can specify anything between 1 minute and 24 hours.
If you specify a bot or alias ID that doesn't exist, you receive a BadRequestException.
If the locale doesn't exist in the bot, or if the locale hasn't been enables for the alias, you receive a BadRequestException.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.DeleteSessionRequest.BotAliasId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property BotAliasId.
The alias identifier in use for the bot that contains the session data.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.DeleteSessionRequest.BotId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property BotId.
The identifier of the bot that contains the session data.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.DeleteSessionRequest.LocaleId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property LocaleId.
The locale where the session is in use.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.DeleteSessionRequest.SessionId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SessionId.
The identifier of the session to delete.

member.name: T:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.DeleteSessionResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the DeleteSession operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.DeleteSessionResponse.BotAliasId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property BotAliasId.
The alias identifier in use for the bot that contained the session data.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.DeleteSessionResponse.BotId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property BotId.
The identifier of the bot that contained the session data.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.DeleteSessionResponse.LocaleId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property LocaleId.
The locale where the session was used.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.DeleteSessionResponse.SessionId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SessionId.
The identifier of the deleted session.

member.name: T:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.DialogAction
member.summary: The next action that Amazon Lex V2 should take.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.DialogAction.SlotToElicit
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SlotToElicit.
The name of the slot that should be elicited from the user.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.DialogAction.Type
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Type.
The next action that the bot should take in its interaction with the user. The possible values are:
Close - Indicates that there will not be a response from the user. For example, the statement "Your order has been placed" does not require a response.
ConfirmIntent - The next action is asking the user if the intent is complete and ready to be fulfilled. This is a yes/no question such as "Place the order?"
Delegate - The next action is determined by Amazon Lex V2.
ElicitSlot - The next action is to elicit a slot value from the user.

member.name: T:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.GetSessionRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the GetSession operation. Returns session information for a specified bot, alias, and user.
For example, you can use this operation to retrieve session information for a user that has left a long-running session in use.
If the bot, alias, or session identifier doesn't exist, Amazon Lex V2 returns a BadRequestException. If the locale doesn't exist or is not enabled for the alias, you receive a BadRequestException.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.GetSessionRequest.BotAliasId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property BotAliasId.
The alias identifier in use for the bot that contains the session data.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.GetSessionRequest.BotId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property BotId.
The identifier of the bot that contains the session data.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.GetSessionRequest.LocaleId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property LocaleId.
The locale where the session is in use.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.GetSessionRequest.SessionId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SessionId.
The identifier of the session to return.

member.name: T:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.GetSessionResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the GetSession operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.GetSessionResponse.Interpretations
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Interpretations.
A list of intents that Amazon Lex V2 determined might satisfy the user's utterance.
Each interpretation includes the intent, a score that indicates how confident Amazon Lex V2 is that the interpretation is the correct one, and an optional sentiment response that indicates the sentiment expressed in the utterance.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.GetSessionResponse.Messages
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Messages.
A list of messages that were last sent to the user. The messages are ordered based on the order that your returned the messages from your Lambda function or the order that messages are defined in the bot.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.GetSessionResponse.SessionId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SessionId.
The identifier of the returned session.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.GetSessionResponse.SessionStateValue
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SessionStateValue.
Represents the current state of the dialog between the user and the bot.
You can use this to determine the progress of the conversation and what the next action might be.

member.name: T:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.ImageResponseCard
member.summary:
A card that is shown to the user by a messaging platform. You define the contents of the card, the card is displayed by the platform.
When you use a response card, the response from the user is constrained to the text associated with a button on the card.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.ImageResponseCard.Buttons
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Buttons.
A list of buttons that should be displayed on the response card. The arrangement of the buttons is determined by the platform that displays the button.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.ImageResponseCard.ImageUrl
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ImageUrl.
The URL of an image to display on the response card. The image URL must be publicly available so that the platform displaying the response card has access to the image.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.ImageResponseCard.Subtitle
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Subtitle.
The subtitle to display on the response card. The format of the subtitle is determined by the platform displaying the response card.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.ImageResponseCard.Title
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Title.
The title to display on the response card. The format of the title is determined by the platform displaying the response card.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.Intent.ConfirmationState

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.Intent.Name
member.summary:

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.Intent.Slots
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Slots.
A map of all of the slots for the intent. The name of the slot maps to the value of the slot. If a slot has not been filled, the value is null.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.Intent.State
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property State.
Contains fulfillment information for the intent.

member.name: T:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.Interpretation
member.summary: An intent that Amazon Lex V2 determined might satisfy the user's utterance. The intents are ordered by the confidence score.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.Interpretation.Intent
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Intent.
A list of intents that might satisfy the user's utterance. The intents are ordered by the confidence score.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.Interpretation.NluConfidence
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NluConfidence.
Determines the threshold where Amazon Lex V2 will insert the AMAZON.FallbackIntent, AMAZON.KendraSearchIntent, or both when returning alternative intents in a response. AMAZON.FallbackIntent and AMAZON.KendraSearchIntent are only inserted if they are configured for the bot.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.Interpretation.SentimentResponse
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SentimentResponse.
The sentiment expressed in an utterance.
When the bot is configured to send utterances to Amazon Comprehend for sentiment analysis, this field contains the result of the analysis.

member.name: T:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.Message
member.summary: Container for text that is returned to the customer..

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.Message.Content
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Content.
The text of the message.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.Message.ContentType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContentType.
Indicates the type of response.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.Message.ImageResponseCard
member.summary: Gets and sets the property ImageResponseCard.

member.name: T:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.PutSessionRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the PutSession operation. Creates a new session or modifies an existing session with an Amazon Lex V2 bot. Use this operation to enable your application to set the state of the bot.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.PutSessionRequest.BotAliasId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property BotAliasId.
The alias identifier of the bot that receives the session data.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.PutSessionRequest.BotId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property BotId.
The identifier of the bot that receives the session data.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.PutSessionRequest.LocaleId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property LocaleId.
The locale where the session is in use.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.PutSessionRequest.Messages
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Messages.
A list of messages to send to the user. Messages are sent in the order that they are defined in the list.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.PutSessionRequest.RequestAttributes
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RequestAttributes.
Request-specific information passed between Amazon Lex V2 and the client application.
The namespace x-amz-lex: is reserved for special attributes. Don't create any request attributes with the prefix x-amz-lex:.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.PutSessionRequest.ResponseContentType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ResponseContentType.
The message that Amazon Lex V2 returns in the response can be either text or speech depending on the value of this parameter.
If the value is text/plain; charset=utf-8, Amazon Lex V2 returns text in the response.

member.name: T:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.RecognizeTextRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the RecognizeText operation. Sends user input to Amazon Lex V2. Client applications use this API to send requests to Amazon Lex V2 at runtime. Amazon Lex V2 then interprets the user input using the machine learning model that it build for the bot.
In response, Amazon Lex V2 returns the next message to convey to the user and an optional response card to display.
If the optional post-fulfillment response is specified, the messages are returned as follows. For more information, see PostFulfillmentStatusSpecification.
Success message - Returned if the Lambda function completes successfully and the intent state is fulfilled or ready fulfillment if the message is present.
Failed message - The failed message is returned if the Lambda function throws an exception or if the Lambda function returns a failed intent state without a message.
Timeout message - If you don't configure a timeout message and a timeout, and the Lambda function doesn't return within 30 seconds, the timeout message is returned. If you configure a timeout, the timeout message is returned when the period times out.
For more information, see Completion message.

member.name: T:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.RecognizeUtteranceRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the RecognizeUtterance operation. Sends user input to Amazon Lex V2. You can send text or speech. Clients use this API to send text and audio requests to Amazon Lex V2 at runtime. Amazon Lex V2 interprets the user input using the machine learning model built for the bot.
The following request fields must be compressed with gzip and then base64 encoded before you send them to Amazon Lex V2.
requestAttributes
sessionState
The following response fields are compressed using gzip and then base64 encoded by Amazon Lex V2. Before you can use these fields, you must decode and decompress them.
inputTranscript
interpretations
messages
requestAttributes
sessionState
The example contains a Java application that compresses and encodes a Java object to send to Amazon Lex V2, and a second that decodes and decompresses a response from Amazon Lex V2.
If the optional post-fulfillment response is specified, the messages are returned as follows. For more information, see PostFulfillmentStatusSpecification.
Success message - Returned if the Lambda function completes successfully and the intent state is fulfilled or ready fulfillment if the message is present.
Failed message - The failed message is returned if the Lambda function throws an exception or if the Lambda function returns a failed intent state without a message.
Timeout message - If you don't configure a timeout message and a timeout, and the Lambda function doesn't return within 30 seconds, the timeout message is returned. If you configure a timeout, the timeout message is returned when the period times out.
For more information, see Completion message.

member.summary:

The alias identifier in use for the bot that should receive the request.

member.summary:

The identifier of the bot that should receive the request.

member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InputStream.
User input in PCM or Opus audio format or text format as described in the requestContentType parameter.

member.summary:
Gets and sets the property LocaleId.
The locale where the session is in use.

member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RequestAttributes.
Request-specific information passed between the client application and Amazon Lex V2
The namespace x-amz-lex: is reserved for special attributes. Don't create any request attributes for prefix x-amz-lex:.
The requestAttributes field must be compressed using gzip and then base64 encoded before sending to Amazon Lex V2.

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.RecognizeUtteranceRequest.RequestContentType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RequestContentType.
Indicates the format for audio input or that the content is text. The header must start with one of the following prefixes:
PCM format, audio data must be in little-endian byte order.
audio/l16; rate=16000; channels=1
audio/x-l16; sample-rate=16000; channel-count=1
audio/lpcm; sample-rate=8000; sample-size-bits=16; channel-count=1; is-big-endian=false
Opus format
audio/x-cbr-opus-with-preamble;preamble-size=0;bit-rate=256000;frame-size-milliseconds=4
Text format
text/plain; charset=utf-8

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.RecognizeUtteranceRequest.ResponseContentType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ResponseContentType.
The message that Amazon Lex V2 returns in the response can be either text or speech based on the responseContentType value.
If the value is text/plain;charset=utf-8, Amazon Lex V2 returns text in the response.
If the value begins with audio/, Amazon Lex V2 returns speech in the response. Amazon Lex V2 uses Amazon Polly to generate the speech using the configuration that you specified in the requestContentType parameter. For example, if you specify audio/mpeg as the value, Amazon Lex V2 returns speech in the MPEG format.
If the value is audio/pcm, the speech returned is audio/pcm at 16 KHz in 16-bit, little-endian format.
The following are the accepted values:
audio/mpeg
audio/ogg
audio/pcm (16 KHz)
audio/* (defaults to mpeg)
text/plain; charset=utf-8

member.name: P:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.RecognizeUtteranceResponse.AudioStream
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AudioStream.
The prompt or statement to send to the user. This is based on the bot configuration and context. For example, if Amazon Lex V2 did not understand the user intent, it sends the clarificationPrompt configured for the bot. If the intent requires confirmation before taking the fulfillment action, it sends the confirmationPrompt. Another example: Suppose that the Lambda function successfully fulfilled the intent, and sent a message to convey to the user. Then Amazon Lex V2 sends that message in the response.

member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InputTranscript.
The text used to process the request.
If the input was an audio stream, the inputTranscript field contains the text extracted from the audio stream. This is the text that is actually processed to recognize intents and slot values. You can use this information to determine if Amazon Lex V2 is correctly processing the audio that you send.
The inputTranscript field is compressed with gzip and then base64 encoded. Before you can use the contents of the field, you must decode and decompress the contents. See the example for a simple function to decode and decompress the contents.

member.name: M:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.AmazonLexRuntimeV2Client.#ctor
member.summary:
Constructs AmazonLexRuntimeV2Client with the credentials loaded from the application's default configuration, and if unsuccessful from the Instance Profile service on an EC2 instance.
Example App.config with credentials set.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>

member.name: M:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.AmazonLexRuntimeV2Client.DeleteSession(Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.DeleteSessionRequest)
member.summary:
Removes session information for a specified bot, alias, and user ID.
You can use this operation to restart a conversation with a bot. When you remove a session, the entire history of the session is removed so that you can start again.
You don't need to delete a session. Sessions have a time limit and will expire. Set the session time limit when you create the bot. The default is 5 minutes, but you can specify anything between 1 minute and 24 hours.
If you specify a bot or alias ID that doesn't exist, you receive a BadRequestException.
If the locale doesn't exist in the bot, or if the locale hasn't been enables for the alias, you receive a BadRequestException.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the DeleteSession service method.
member.returns: The response from the DeleteSession service method, as returned by LexRuntimeV2.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for DeleteSession Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.AmazonLexRuntimeV2Client.DeleteSessionAsync(Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.DeleteSessionRequest,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary:
Removes session information for a specified bot, alias, and user ID.
You can use this operation to restart a conversation with a bot. When you remove a session, the entire history of the session is removed so that you can start again.
You don't need to delete a session. Sessions have a time limit and will expire. Set the session time limit when you create the bot. The default is 5 minutes, but you can specify anything between 1 minute and 24 hours.
If you specify a bot or alias ID that doesn't exist, you receive a BadRequestException.
If the locale doesn't exist in the bot, or if the locale hasn't been enables for the alias, you receive a BadRequestException.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the DeleteSession service method.
A cancellation token that can be used by other objects or threads to receive notice of cancellation.
member.returns: The response from the DeleteSession service method, as returned by LexRuntimeV2.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for DeleteSession Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.AmazonLexRuntimeV2Client.GetSession(Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.GetSessionRequest)
member.summary:
Returns session information for a specified bot, alias, and user.
For example, you can use this operation to retrieve session information for a user that has left a long-running session in use.
If the bot, alias, or session identifier doesn't exist, Amazon Lex V2 returns a BadRequestException. If the locale doesn't exist or is not enabled for the alias, you receive a BadRequestException.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the GetSession service method.
member.returns: The response from the GetSession service method, as returned by LexRuntimeV2.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for GetSession Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.AmazonLexRuntimeV2Client.RecognizeText(Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.RecognizeTextRequest)
member.summary:
Sends user input to Amazon Lex V2. Client applications use this API to send requests to Amazon Lex V2 at runtime. Amazon Lex V2 then interprets the user input using the machine learning model that it build for the bot.
In response, Amazon Lex V2 returns the next message to convey to the user and an optional response card to display.
If the optional post-fulfillment response is specified, the messages are returned as follows. For more information, see PostFulfillmentStatusSpecification.
Success message - Returned if the Lambda function completes successfully and the intent state is fulfilled or ready fulfillment if the message is present.
Failed message - The failed message is returned if the Lambda function throws an exception or if the Lambda function returns a failed intent state without a message.
Timeout message - If you don't configure a timeout message and a timeout, and the Lambda function doesn't return within 30 seconds, the timeout message is returned. If you configure a timeout, the timeout message is returned when the period times out.
For more information, see Completion message.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the RecognizeText service method.
member.returns: The response from the RecognizeText service method, as returned by LexRuntimeV2.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for RecognizeText Operation

member.summary:

In response, Amazon Lex V2 returns the next message to convey to the user and an optional response card to display.
If the optional post-fulfillment response is specified, the messages are returned as follows. For more information, see PostFulfillmentStatusSpecification.
Success message - Returned if the Lambda function completes successfully and the intent state is fulfilled or ready fulfillment if the message is present.
Failed message - The failed message is returned if the Lambda function throws an exception or if the Lambda function returns a failed intent state without a message.
Timeout message - If you don't configure a timeout message and a timeout, and the Lambda function doesn't return within 30 seconds, the timeout message is returned. If you configure a timeout, the timeout message is returned when the period times out.
For more information, see Completion message.

A cancellation token that can be used by other objects or threads to receive notice of cancellation.
member.returns: The response from the RecognizeText service method, as returned by LexRuntimeV2.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for RecognizeText Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.AmazonLexRuntimeV2Client.RecognizeUtterance(Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.RecognizeUtteranceRequest)
member.summary:
Sends user input to Amazon Lex V2. You can send text or speech. Clients use this API to send text and audio requests to Amazon Lex V2 at runtime. Amazon Lex V2 interprets the user input using the machine learning model built for the bot.
The following request fields must be compressed with gzip and then base64 encoded before you send them to Amazon Lex V2.
requestAttributes
sessionState
The following response fields are compressed using gzip and then base64 encoded by Amazon Lex V2. Before you can use these fields, you must decode and decompress them.
inputTranscript
interpretations
messages
requestAttributes
sessionState
The example contains a Java application that compresses and encodes a Java object to send to Amazon Lex V2, and a second that decodes and decompresses a response from Amazon Lex V2.
If the optional post-fulfillment response is specified, the messages are returned as follows. For more information, see PostFulfillmentStatusSpecification.
Success message - Returned if the Lambda function completes successfully and the intent state is fulfilled or ready fulfillment if the message is present.
Failed message - The failed message is returned if the Lambda function throws an exception or if the Lambda function returns a failed intent state without a message.
Timeout message - If you don't configure a timeout message and a timeout, and the Lambda function doesn't return within 30 seconds, the timeout message is returned. If you configure a timeout, the timeout message is returned when the period times out.
For more information, see Completion message.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the RecognizeUtterance service method.
member.returns: The response from the RecognizeUtterance service method, as returned by LexRuntimeV2.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for RecognizeUtterance Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.IAmazonLexRuntimeV2.RecognizeText(Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.RecognizeTextRequest)
member.summary:
Sends user input to Amazon Lex V2. Client applications use this API to send requests to Amazon Lex V2 at runtime. Amazon Lex V2 then interprets the user input using the machine learning model that it build for the bot.
In response, Amazon Lex V2 returns the next message to convey to the user and an optional response card to display.
If the optional post-fulfillment response is specified, the messages are returned as follows. For more information, see PostFulfillmentStatusSpecification.
Success message - Returned if the Lambda function completes successfully and the intent state is fulfilled or ready fulfillment if the message is present.
Failed message - The failed message is returned if the Lambda function throws an exception or if the Lambda function returns a failed intent state without a message.
Timeout message - If you don't configure a timeout message and a timeout, and the Lambda function doesn't return within 30 seconds, the timeout message is returned. If you configure a timeout, the timeout message is returned when the period times out.
For more information, see Completion message.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the RecognizeText service method.
member.returns: The response from the RecognizeText service method, as returned by LexRuntimeV2.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for RecognizeText Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.IAmazonLexRuntimeV2.RecognizeUtterance(Amazon.LexRuntimeV2.Model.RecognizeUtteranceRequest)
member.summary:
Sends user input to Amazon Lex V2. You can send text or speech. Clients use this API to send text and audio requests to Amazon Lex V2 at runtime. Amazon Lex V2 interprets the user input using the machine learning model built for the bot.
The following request fields must be compressed with gzip and then base64 encoded before you send them to Amazon Lex V2.
requestAttributes
sessionState
The following response fields are compressed using gzip and then base64 encoded by Amazon Lex V2. Before you can use these fields, you must decode and decompress them.
inputTranscript
interpretations
messages
requestAttributes
sessionState
The example contains a Java application that compresses and encodes a Java object to send to Amazon Lex V2, and a second that decodes and decompresses a response from Amazon Lex V2.
If the optional post-fulfillment response is specified, the messages are returned as follows. For more information, see PostFulfillmentStatusSpecification.
Success message - Returned if the Lambda function completes successfully and the intent state is fulfilled or ready fulfillment if the message is present.
Failed message - The failed message is returned if the Lambda function throws an exception or if the Lambda function returns a failed intent state without a message.
Timeout message - If you don't configure a timeout message and a timeout, and the Lambda function doesn't return within 30 seconds, the timeout message is returned. If you configure a timeout, the timeout message is returned when the period times out.
For more information, see Completion message.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the RecognizeUtterance service method.
member.returns: The response from the RecognizeUtterance service method, as returned by LexRuntimeV2.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for RecognizeUtterance Operation
